data.author: Helpful
data.content: To enable share buybacks, RRR and any other company has to go through a process. That involves going to the High Court and spending money (not a lot but some). A company wouldn't want to go through that process unless it knew it had shareholder support for it. The vote will give the company the authority to pursue it or not. If things work out: VUP money, Glencore case, housing JV and new licences, then RRR will be over-capitalised. It has two ways of dealing with that, it pays dividends (not tax efficient) or buys shares back and cancels them You would only buy back shares and cancel them if you thought that the market undervalues the shares. See UJO, POW and others. AST did it differently by issuing preference shares with the right to any proceeds from the case against the Slovenian Government. Up to the shareholders. Note that the most prolific posters on here are not shareholders. Some remarkably tedious posters have never been shareholders. DYOR

data.author: Helpful
data.content: Boring Boy, it is not to buy back shares in the share premium account. If you really are the World's Greatest Part Qualified Accountant as you claim, you would understand what the Share Premium Account actually is. You quite obviously don't. There are no shares in the Share Premium Account. The Share Premium Account is a monetary credit to help balance everything out using double entry book-keeping. The Share Premium Account is the accounting credit for the difference between the nominal value of the shares issued and the actual price paid when the shares are issued. https://x.com/i/grok/share/87715dbfc19244c386d5b109bbbafa91 I know you said you are a bit rusty but you need to hold of some WD40 super-strength and get working it hard. If RRR gets the necessary authority and proceeds with share buys it can do it two ways: it goes in the market, buys shares and cancels them or it does a reverse tender or reverse rights issue and cancels them once they have bought them. VCTs do share buy backs as a standard thing. If you knew absolutely ANYTHING about market practice, you would understand this. zzzzzzz As I have said before, I find it hard to believe that you are really this dumb. DYOR

data.content: ASX ANNOUNCEMENT ASX: DAL 14 January 2026 Request for Trading Halt ______________________________________________________________________________ Market Announcement Office ASX Limited Via Email: tradinghaltsperth@asx.com.au Dalaroo Metals Ltd (Company) requests an immediate trading halt be granted by ASX in respect of its securities from the commencement of trading on 14 January 2026. For the purposes of ASX Listing Rule 17.1, the Company provides the following information in relation to its request: a) The trading halt is requested pending an announcement in relation to material exploration results from its Blue Lagoon Project in Greenland; b) The Company requests that the trading halt end on the earlier of the commencement of normal trading on 16 January 2026, or when the anticipated announcement referred to in (a) above is released to the market; and c) The Company is not aware of any reason why the trading halt should not be granted, nor of any other information necessary to inform the market about the trading halt.

data.author: DAVID.M
data.content: Banburyboy, lawsuits are generally a waste of time for a company like Red Rock, depending of course on who you may be suing and for how much. The general rules are: 1. The legal fees are exorbitant. 2. I takes years. 3. At the end, the company you are suing has no money. The exception of course, is where the amount is very large and the prospects are good. In this case you could get legal representation on a no cost basis for a proportion of the win. 1 still applies in the sense of how much the lawyers will take, and 2 still applies in terms of the time.

data.author: DAVID.M
data.content: Banburyboy, I do think it existed at some point, based on the RNS below. Whether it still exists is anyone's guess. If it no longer exists, then I doubt whether Red Rock could do anything about it. I have no idea of the value, so pursuing it might not be worthwhile. What it does prove, is that if you are juggling too many balls and you take your eye off some of them, disaster can strike. Copper/cobalt in the DRC, lithium in Zimbabwe or perhaps Mozambique. We all know what some African ports are like. Very likely it's long gone. 15/11/2023 2:09pm UK Regulatory Red Rock Resources (LSE:RRR) Historical Stock Chart From Jan 2023 to Jan 2026 Click Here for more Red Rock Resources Charts. TIDMRRR RNS Number : 5903T Red Rock Resources plc 15 November 2023 Red Rock Resources Plc ("Red Rock" or the "Company") Lithium Update - Exports 15 November 2023 Red Rock Resources Plc, the natural resource exploration and development company with interests in gold, copper, cobalt, lithium and other minerals, announces an update in relation to the Company's lithium operations in Zimbabwe. The Company has 200 tons of lithium ore prepared for export and the first truck has now left Harare for the Mozambican port of Beira. Red Rock Chairman Andrew Bell comments : "We are now beginning to export lithium ore from Zimbabwe and expect this to be a growing part of the Company's business. We continue in parallel to pursue the consolidation and improvement of our lithium estate and the permitting of additional areas, in order to create long-term visibility of earnings. Further announcements will be made as we pass additional milestones." No further announcements, to my knowledge, so no further milestones. I think it's a waste of time even discussing the subject, as it's another irrelevance. Having said that it's probably just as relevant as the price of gold (which Red Rock doesn't produce), or the price of copper (the one that got away).

For the purposes of ASX Listing Rule 17.1, the Company provides the following information in relation to its request: a) The trading halt is requested pending an announcement in relation to material exploration results from its Blue Lagoon Project in Greenland; b) The Company requests that the trading halt end on the earlier of the commencement of normal trading on 16 January 2026, or when the anticipated announcement referred to in (a) above is released to the market; and c) The Company is not aware of any reason why the trading halt should not be granted, nor of any other information necessary to inform the market about the trading halt.

data.author: DAVID.M
data.content: I think some of the argument about copper is about semantics. We may have interests that are exploring for copper, but I am not aware of any JORC resource owned by those interests, nor any saleable copper that we own. My concerns with Red Rock surround whether the company has anything saleable that someone else might want to buy. Quite apart from the monthly running costs for the company, we owe POW £534,449.67 at the end of March. At present, the only two options for ready cash, if all goes well, would be the Soma warrants and the Dalaroo shares, both subject to events falling in Red Rock's favour. The current silence from the company doesn't help alleviate any of those concerns.

data.author: Helpful
data.content: Mr Attention-seeker, this is what the LIFE Offering document says, I know you know because you read everything. "Each Unit will consist of one common share of the Company (a “Share”) and one-half of one common share purchase warrant (each whole warrant, a “Warrant”). Each Warrant will be exercisable to acquire an additional Share (a “Warrant Share”) at an exercise price of $2.00 per Warrant Share for a period of 36 months following the Closing Date (as defined herein). The Warrants will be subject to an accelerated expiry provision such that if, for any 30 consecutive trading days (the “Premium Trading Days”) during the unexpired term of the Warrants, the closing price of the Shares exceeds $3.00, the expiry date will be accelerated to 30 calendar days (the “Acceleration Clause”). The activation of the Acceleration Clause will be announced by press release and the 30-day period will commence 7 days after the last Premium Trading Day." So for the accelerated exercise to come into play, Soma Gold share price has to close over CAD3.00 for 30 consecutive days, 7 days notice is required and then 30 days in which to exercise. Remember you said that the warrants would be worthless? So if for any 30 days period the SP closes over CAD3.00 for 29 days but one day it closes below CAD3.00 then the clock restarts. The seven days starts when the company issues the notice. So there is plenty of warning. DYOR

data.author: DAVID.M
data.content: Red Rock has large debts in the region of £10M. The ongoing monthly costs of running the business equate to around £250,000, a significant portion of which are finance costs. Against this Red Rock has a number of assets some of which are possibly saleable in the relatively short term, although the most significant of which are not. Saleable in the relatively short term: Soma warrants - with the share price falling back to around CAD 2.06 and the warrant exercise at CAD 2.00 this isn't going to raise much. Dalaroo shares - 13,250,000 currently AUD 0.63 currently worth about £425,000 subject to completion of the deal, and the ability to place in the market. Lithium - if it can be found. Burkino Faso assets - if a value could be established. Not saleable in the short term: RRAL - RRR don't own until the £534,449 paid to POW. Migori - awaiting situation with the licence renewal to be clarified. Elephant Oil stake - awaiting an IPO that never seems to happen. Mt Ida royalty if developed. I am sure that that there are assets I have probably missed, but the basic fact of life is that Red Rock are going through around £250,000 per month just to keep the lights on. The immediately saleable assets (subject to more luck that is normally associated with Red Rock/AB) might keep the lights on for 2 months but wouldn't address the underlying debt problem of the remaining £10M. What then about run rate revenue. Where could this come from? The house building project if it ever gets off the ground isn't likely to contribute anything before towards the end of 2026 if we are lucky. Burkino Faso - if we want revenue here we actually have to do something rather that pray for gold to fall from the skies. The price of gold, the price of copper, the price of silver, the price of iron are all irrelevant. Firstly they assume that Red Rock has prime assets that others are queuing up to buy. Secondly this ignores the fact that Red Rock is in a race against time. How quickly is anything saleable vs both the £250K monthly costs and the level of patience of the allegedly supportive lenders. The other factor for shareholders to consider is how much dilution will be needed and at what discount will the market demand. The only real game in town is the DRC arbitration settlement. The fact that it has been imminent for months, and now has been in the first batch to be heard for the last 2 months, doesn't inspire confidence. What else doesn't inspire confidence is the silence from Andrew Bell. No news, no broadcasts on X, nothing.

data.author: Helpful
data.content: Mr Attention-seeker, this is what the LIFE Offering document says, I know you know because you read everything. "Each Unit will consist of one common share of the Company (a “Share”) and one-half of one common share purchase warrant (each whole warrant, a “Warrant”). Each Warrant will be exercisable to acquire an additional Share (a “Warrant Share”) at an exercise price of $2.00 per Warrant Share for a period of 36 months following the Closing Date (as defined herein). The Warrants will be subject to an accelerated expiry provision such that if, for any 30 consecutive trading days (the “Premium Trading Days”) during the unexpired term of the Warrants, the closing price of the Shares exceeds $3.00, the expiry date will be accelerated to 30 calendar days (the “Acceleration Clause”). The activation of the Acceleration Clause will be announced by press release and the 30-day period will commence 7 days after the last Premium Trading Day." So for the accelerated exercise to come into play, Soma Gold share price has to close over CAD3.00 for 30 consecutive days, 7 days notice is required and then 30 days in which to exercise. Remember you said that the warrants would be worthless? So if for any 30 days period the SP closes over CAD3.00 for 29 days but one day it closes below CAD3.00 then the clock restarts. The seven days starts when the company issues the notice. So there is plenty of warning. DYOR

data.content: I think some of the argument about copper is about semantics. We may have interests that are exploring for copper, but I am not aware of any JORC resource owned by those interests, nor any saleable copper that we own. My concerns with Red Rock surround whether the company has anything saleable that someone else might want to buy. Quite apart from the monthly running costs for the company, we owe POW £534,449.67 at the end of March. At present, the only two options for ready cash, if all goes well, would be the Soma warrants and the Dalaroo shares, both subject to events falling in Red Rock's favour. The current silence from the company doesn't help alleviate any of those concerns.

data.author: DAVID.M
data.content: Red Rock has large debts in the region of £10M. The ongoing monthly costs of running the business equate to around £250,000, a significant portion of which are finance costs. Against this Red Rock has a number of assets some of which are possibly saleable in the relatively short term, although the most significant of which are not. Saleable in the relatively short term: Soma warrants - with the share price falling back to around CAD 2.06 and the warrant exercise at CAD 2.00 this isn't going to raise much. Dalaroo shares - 13,250,000 currently AUD 0.63 currently worth about £425,000 subject to completion of the deal, and the ability to place in the market. Lithium - if it can be found. Burkino Faso assets - if a value could be established. Not saleable in the short term: RRAL - RRR don't own until the £534,449 paid to POW. Migori - awaiting situation with the licence renewal to be clarified. Elephant Oil stake - awaiting an IPO that never seems to happen. Mt Ida royalty if developed. I am sure that that there are assets I have probably missed, but the basic fact of life is that Red Rock are going through around £250,000 per month just to keep the lights on. The immediately saleable assets (subject to more luck that is normally associated with Red Rock/AB) might keep the lights on for 2 months but wouldn't address the underlying debt problem of the remaining £10M. What then about run rate revenue. Where could this come from? The house building project if it ever gets off the ground isn't likely to contribute anything before towards the end of 2026 if we are lucky. Burkino Faso - if we want revenue here we actually have to do something rather that pray for gold to fall from the skies. The price of gold, the price of copper, the price of silver, the price of iron are all irrelevant. Firstly they assume that Red Rock has prime assets that others are queuing up to buy. Secondly this ignores the fact that Red Rock is in a race against time. How quickly is anything saleable vs both the £250K monthly costs and the level of patience of the allegedly supportive lenders. The other factor for shareholders to consider is how much dilution will be needed and at what discount will the market demand. The only real game in town is the DRC arbitration settlement. The fact that it has been imminent for months, and now has been in the first batch to be heard for the last 2 months, doesn't inspire confidence. What else doesn't inspire confidence is the silence from Andrew Bell. No news, no broadcasts on X, nothing.

data.author: Helpful
data.content: Mr Attention-seeker, this is what the LIFE Offering document says, I know you know because you read everything. "Each Unit will consist of one common share of the Company (a “Share”) and one-half of one common share purchase warrant (each whole warrant, a “Warrant”). Each Warrant will be exercisable to acquire an additional Share (a “Warrant Share”) at an exercise price of $2.00 per Warrant Share for a period of 36 months following the Closing Date (as defined herein). The Warrants will be subject to an accelerated expiry provision such that if, for any 30 consecutive trading days (the “Premium Trading Days”) during the unexpired term of the Warrants, the closing price of the Shares exceeds $3.00, the expiry date will be accelerated to 30 calendar days (the “Acceleration Clause”). The activation of the Acceleration Clause will be announced by press release and the 30-day period will commence 7 days after the last Premium Trading Day." So for the accelerated exercise to come into play, Soma Gold share price has to close over CAD3.00 for 30 consecutive days, 7 days notice is required and then 30 days in which to exercise. Remember you said that the warrants would be worthless? So if for any 30 days period the SP closes over CAD3.00 for 29 days but one day it closes below CAD3.00 then the clock restarts. The seven days starts when the company issues the notice. So there is plenty of warning. DYOR

data.author: DAVID.M
data.content: I think the header here illustrates one of the problems that Red Rock has generally. AB is trying to find a deal or business opportunity to get Red Rock out of it's current debt and revenue problem. We don't yet know whether anything will happen in the DRC in the fullness of time, but it's time that Red Rock doesn't have. One can debate forever whether Red Rock has good projects, bad projects, or indifferent projects, but the big question is whether Red Rock can monetize any of them without waiting months for a deal to conclude. The conditional sale of the Ivory Coast licences was announced on October 15th and still hasn't completed. That's nearly 4 months and we don't know how long it took to get to the announcement. We also only know that the deal should complete by the end of March, so if that happens it would be around 5 1/2 months. Any deal is going to require due diligence so it's reasonable to expect no other sale could be finalized before sometime in May at the earliest. We have the POW payment at the end of March, which has already cost £80,000 in deferral fees so it now sits at £534,449, and there are only 3 ways to find that amount assuming the ongoing running costs have been taken into account in the recent placing. 1. Sale of Dalaroo shares assuming the deal completes before then. 2. Sale of Soma warrants assuming the value is sufficient to make it worthwhile. 3. Another placing. I should probably have said 4 things to accommodate the DRC arbitration settlement, but after a year of waiting on the imminent announcement, sadly this just doesn't seem likely and Red Rock certainly couldn't bank on it. Whatever good projects Red Rock may find for the future, time is their enemy.

data.author: DAVID.M
data.content: Red Rock has large debts in the region of £10M. The ongoing monthly costs of running the business equate to around £250,000, a significant portion of which are finance costs. Against this Red Rock has a number of assets some of which are possibly saleable in the relatively short term, although the most significant of which are not. Saleable in the relatively short term: Soma warrants - with the share price falling back to around CAD 2.06 and the warrant exercise at CAD 2.00 this isn't going to raise much. Dalaroo shares - 13,250,000 currently AUD 0.63 currently worth about £425,000 subject to completion of the deal, and the ability to place in the market. Lithium - if it can be found. Burkino Faso assets - if a value could be established. Not saleable in the short term: RRAL - RRR don't own until the £534,449 paid to POW. Migori - awaiting situation with the licence renewal to be clarified. Elephant Oil stake - awaiting an IPO that never seems to happen. Mt Ida royalty if developed. I am sure that that there are assets I have probably missed, but the basic fact of life is that Red Rock are going through around £250,000 per month just to keep the lights on. The immediately saleable assets (subject to more luck that is normally associated with Red Rock/AB) might keep the lights on for 2 months but wouldn't address the underlying debt problem of the remaining £10M. What then about run rate revenue. Where could this come from? The house building project if it ever gets off the ground isn't likely to contribute anything before towards the end of 2026 if we are lucky. Burkino Faso - if we want revenue here we actually have to do something rather that pray for gold to fall from the skies. The price of gold, the price of copper, the price of silver, the price of iron are all irrelevant. Firstly they assume that Red Rock has prime assets that others are queuing up to buy. Secondly this ignores the fact that Red Rock is in a race against time. How quickly is anything saleable vs both the £250K monthly costs and the level of patience of the allegedly supportive lenders. The other factor for shareholders to consider is how much dilution will be needed and at what discount will the market demand. The only real game in town is the DRC arbitration settlement. The fact that it has been imminent for months, and now has been in the first batch to be heard for the last 2 months, doesn't inspire confidence. What else doesn't inspire confidence is the silence from Andrew Bell. No news, no broadcasts on X, nothing.

data.author: specinvestor99
data.content: These assays are taking a real long time 18 October 2024 Red Rock Resources Plc, ("Red Rock" or "the Company"), is a natural resource development company with interests in gold and base metals, principally in Africa and Australia. The Company notes that it has submitted and remitted payment for samples to be tested by SGS in Yamoussoukro and expects results as soon as payment is received. The samples include 75 termite mound samples from its two granted Côte d'Ivoire licences: the Yamoussoukro licence, covering some alluvial areas, and 19 rock chip samples from the Djekanou licence. All samples were tested for multielements and those from Djekanou tested in addition for their potential lithium content.

data.author: Helpful
data.content: Mr Attention-seeker, this is what the LIFE Offering document says, I know you know because you read everything. "Each Unit will consist of one common share of the Company (a “Share”) and one-half of one common share purchase warrant (each whole warrant, a “Warrant”). Each Warrant will be exercisable to acquire an additional Share (a “Warrant Share”) at an exercise price of $2.00 per Warrant Share for a period of 36 months following the Closing Date (as defined herein). The Warrants will be subject to an accelerated expiry provision such that if, for any 30 consecutive trading days (the “Premium Trading Days”) during the unexpired term of the Warrants, the closing price of the Shares exceeds $3.00, the expiry date will be accelerated to 30 calendar days (the “Acceleration Clause”). The activation of the Acceleration Clause will be announced by press release and the 30-day period will commence 7 days after the last Premium Trading Day." So for the accelerated exercise to come into play, Soma Gold share price has to close over CAD3.00 for 30 consecutive days, 7 days notice is required and then 30 days in which to exercise. Remember you said that the warrants would be worthless? So if for any 30 days period the SP closes over CAD3.00 for 29 days but one day it closes below CAD3.00 then the clock restarts. The seven days starts when the company issues the notice. So there is plenty of warning. DYOR

data.author: DAVID.M
data.content: I think some of the argument about copper is about semantics. We may have interests that are exploring for copper, but I am not aware of any JORC resource owned by those interests, nor any saleable copper that we own. My concerns with Red Rock surround whether the company has anything saleable that someone else might want to buy. Quite apart from the monthly running costs for the company, we owe POW £534,449.67 at the end of March. At present, the only two options for ready cash, if all goes well, would be the Soma warrants and the Dalaroo shares, both subject to events falling in Red Rock's favour. The current silence from the company doesn't help alleviate any of those concerns.

data.author: DAVID.M
data.content: I think the header here illustrates one of the problems that Red Rock has generally. AB is trying to find a deal or business opportunity to get Red Rock out of it's current debt and revenue problem. We don't yet know whether anything will happen in the DRC in the fullness of time, but it's time that Red Rock doesn't have. One can debate forever whether Red Rock has good projects, bad projects, or indifferent projects, but the big question is whether Red Rock can monetize any of them without waiting months for a deal to conclude. The conditional sale of the Ivory Coast licences was announced on October 15th and still hasn't completed. That's nearly 4 months and we don't know how long it took to get to the announcement. We also only know that the deal should complete by the end of March, so if that happens it would be around 5 1/2 months. Any deal is going to require due diligence so it's reasonable to expect no other sale could be finalized before sometime in May at the earliest. We have the POW payment at the end of March, which has already cost £80,000 in deferral fees so it now sits at £534,449, and there are only 3 ways to find that amount assuming the ongoing running costs have been taken into account in the recent placing. 1. Sale of Dalaroo shares assuming the deal completes before then. 2. Sale of Soma warrants assuming the value is sufficient to make it worthwhile. 3. Another placing. I should probably have said 4 things to accommodate the DRC arbitration settlement, but after a year of waiting on the imminent announcement, sadly this just doesn't seem likely and Red Rock certainly couldn't bank on it. Whatever good projects Red Rock may find for the future, time is their enemy.

data.author: DAVID.M
data.content: Red Rock has large debts in the region of £10M. The ongoing monthly costs of running the business equate to around £250,000, a significant portion of which are finance costs. Against this Red Rock has a number of assets some of which are possibly saleable in the relatively short term, although the most significant of which are not. Saleable in the relatively short term: Soma warrants - with the share price falling back to around CAD 2.06 and the warrant exercise at CAD 2.00 this isn't going to raise much. Dalaroo shares - 13,250,000 currently AUD 0.63 currently worth about £425,000 subject to completion of the deal, and the ability to place in the market. Lithium - if it can be found. Burkino Faso assets - if a value could be established. Not saleable in the short term: RRAL - RRR don't own until the £534,449 paid to POW. Migori - awaiting situation with the licence renewal to be clarified. Elephant Oil stake - awaiting an IPO that never seems to happen. Mt Ida royalty if developed. I am sure that that there are assets I have probably missed, but the basic fact of life is that Red Rock are going through around £250,000 per month just to keep the lights on. The immediately saleable assets (subject to more luck that is normally associated with Red Rock/AB) might keep the lights on for 2 months but wouldn't address the underlying debt problem of the remaining £10M. What then about run rate revenue. Where could this come from? The house building project if it ever gets off the ground isn't likely to contribute anything before towards the end of 2026 if we are lucky. Burkino Faso - if we want revenue here we actually have to do something rather that pray for gold to fall from the skies. The price of gold, the price of copper, the price of silver, the price of iron are all irrelevant. Firstly they assume that Red Rock has prime assets that others are queuing up to buy. Secondly this ignores the fact that Red Rock is in a race against time. How quickly is anything saleable vs both the £250K monthly costs and the level of patience of the allegedly supportive lenders. The other factor for shareholders to consider is how much dilution will be needed and at what discount will the market demand. The only real game in town is the DRC arbitration settlement. The fact that it has been imminent for months, and now has been in the first batch to be heard for the last 2 months, doesn't inspire confidence. What else doesn't inspire confidence is the silence from Andrew Bell. No news, no broadcasts on X, nothing.

data.author: Helpful
data.content: Mr Attention-seeker, this is what the LIFE Offering document says, I know you know because you read everything. "Each Unit will consist of one common share of the Company (a “Share”) and one-half of one common share purchase warrant (each whole warrant, a “Warrant”). Each Warrant will be exercisable to acquire an additional Share (a “Warrant Share”) at an exercise price of $2.00 per Warrant Share for a period of 36 months following the Closing Date (as defined herein). The Warrants will be subject to an accelerated expiry provision such that if, for any 30 consecutive trading days (the “Premium Trading Days”) during the unexpired term of the Warrants, the closing price of the Shares exceeds $3.00, the expiry date will be accelerated to 30 calendar days (the “Acceleration Clause”). The activation of the Acceleration Clause will be announced by press release and the 30-day period will commence 7 days after the last Premium Trading Day." So for the accelerated exercise to come into play, Soma Gold share price has to close over CAD3.00 for 30 consecutive days, 7 days notice is required and then 30 days in which to exercise. Remember you said that the warrants would be worthless? So if for any 30 days period the SP closes over CAD3.00 for 29 days but one day it closes below CAD3.00 then the clock restarts. The seven days starts when the company issues the notice. So there is plenty of warning. DYOR

data.author: DAVID.M
data.content: I think some of the argument about copper is about semantics. We may have interests that are exploring for copper, but I am not aware of any JORC resource owned by those interests, nor any saleable copper that we own. My concerns with Red Rock surround whether the company has anything saleable that someone else might want to buy. Quite apart from the monthly running costs for the company, we owe POW £534,449.67 at the end of March. At present, the only two options for ready cash, if all goes well, would be the Soma warrants and the Dalaroo shares, both subject to events falling in Red Rock's favour. The current silence from the company doesn't help alleviate any of those concerns.

data.title: Update
data.full_content:
Today 07:00
RNS Number : 4889S
Red Rock Resources plc
11 February 2026
Red Rock Resources PLC
("Red Rock" or the "Company")
Update
11 February 2026
Red Rock Resources Plc, the natural resource exploration and development company with interests in
gold, base and battery metals, and hydrocarbons principally
in Africa and Australia announces an update, further to those of 23 October 2025, 25 November 2025 particularly as they relate to developments in the Democratic Republic of Congo ("DRC"), and further to the Annual Report published on 22 December 2025.
DRC
JV
It was noted on 23rd October 2025 and 25th November 2025 that pursuant to the Koto Red Rock JV the Company and its partners were seeking to identify appropriate copper-cobalt and gold licences and expected shortly
to visit some of the short-listed licences, and that updates would be issued.
The Company was looking for (a) a grant pursuant to the JV's partnership with Government agencies; plus either (b) licences it might take over and hold in its own name, or/and (c) licences it might acquire through private treaty.
A number of possibilities have been reviewed or have resulted in exploratory meetings. The Company has recently signed an NDA and started its due diligence assessment involving external consultants of a privately held potential copper-cobalt mining project in the Kambove region of Katanga.
DRC Litigation
A judgment and conclusion of the proceedings between the Company and VUP as referred to in the Company's previous announcements remains pending, and the Company is confident that its position will be upheld.
Other
In the last two weeks the Company through Red Rock Australasia Ltd has applied for renewal of two licences in Victoria, made partial surrenders in relation to one of those licences and a total surrender of a third small licence isolated from the Company's other properties, and has brought in another company to share office costs. As part of this rationalisation and forward planning, the Company expects to receive the final draft of a third party professional assessment of its licences and of alternative options going forward. At the same time the Company has begun discussions with potential regional partners.
In the last two weeks in Kenya the Company through its local representative has progressed the renewal discussions on its gold assets to the point where it hopes to arrive at an outcome that will allow activities to restart with the aim of obtaining production licences.
Red Rock chairman Andrew Bell comments
:
"The DRC licence on which we have signed an NDA requires some due diligence, following which we will make a further announcement. There is a possibility that we may have identified a licence which meets our requirements for all potential copper/cobalt projects in the DRC, which are (1) that they should be first class in terms of prospective grade and size, (2) that they are with a reliable counterparty that will agree reasonable terms, and (3) that they should be able to generate production either immediately or on a short timeframe.
We continue to review other licence opportunities.
We see enough opportunities to that we shall be able to identify and access quality projects there, as we have done before. Dealing with private parties offers the opportunity to move quickly, while the World continues to need more copper."
For further information, please contact:
Andrew Bell
0207 747 9990
Chairman
Red Rock Resources Plc
Roland Cornish/ Rosalind Hill Abrahams
0207 628 3396
NOMAD
Beaumont Cornish Limited

rns@lseg.com

data.author: DAVID.M
data.content: Thanks Banburyboy. The price you mentioned 0.07p is more or less the level I was thinking, largely for the reasons you described. Without the DRC money it looks like he is going to try to firefight the immediate problems, in the hope that one of the longer term projects will eventually provide relief. This might stave off disaster, but his main issue is that he needs to more than keep up with the interest accumulating on the debt. It's a race against time. His problem is that if he tries to go to the market for any amount large enough to make a dent, the best price he is likely to get is at most 0.025p. At that level £1,000,000 in the kitty is 4,000,000,000 shares, and that would only stave off problems for a few months, with over half of that needed to pay POW. It's hard to see a way forward without the DRC settlement. He very much needs to pull a rabbit out of the hat.

data.author: DAVID.M
data.content: I think the header here illustrates one of the problems that Red Rock has generally. AB is trying to find a deal or business opportunity to get Red Rock out of it's current debt and revenue problem. We don't yet know whether anything will happen in the DRC in the fullness of time, but it's time that Red Rock doesn't have. One can debate forever whether Red Rock has good projects, bad projects, or indifferent projects, but the big question is whether Red Rock can monetize any of them without waiting months for a deal to conclude. The conditional sale of the Ivory Coast licences was announced on October 15th and still hasn't completed. That's nearly 4 months and we don't know how long it took to get to the announcement. We also only know that the deal should complete by the end of March, so if that happens it would be around 5 1/2 months. Any deal is going to require due diligence so it's reasonable to expect no other sale could be finalized before sometime in May at the earliest. We have the POW payment at the end of March, which has already cost £80,000 in deferral fees so it now sits at £534,449, and there are only 3 ways to find that amount assuming the ongoing running costs have been taken into account in the recent placing. 1. Sale of Dalaroo shares assuming the deal completes before then. 2. Sale of Soma warrants assuming the value is sufficient to make it worthwhile. 3. Another placing. I should probably have said 4 things to accommodate the DRC arbitration settlement, but after a year of waiting on the imminent announcement, sadly this just doesn't seem likely and Red Rock certainly couldn't bank on it. Whatever good projects Red Rock may find for the future, time is their enemy.

data.author: DAVID.M
data.content: Red Rock has large debts in the region of £10M. The ongoing monthly costs of running the business equate to around £250,000, a significant portion of which are finance costs. Against this Red Rock has a number of assets some of which are possibly saleable in the relatively short term, although the most significant of which are not. Saleable in the relatively short term: Soma warrants - with the share price falling back to around CAD 2.06 and the warrant exercise at CAD 2.00 this isn't going to raise much. Dalaroo shares - 13,250,000 currently AUD 0.63 currently worth about £425,000 subject to completion of the deal, and the ability to place in the market. Lithium - if it can be found. Burkino Faso assets - if a value could be established. Not saleable in the short term: RRAL - RRR don't own until the £534,449 paid to POW. Migori - awaiting situation with the licence renewal to be clarified. Elephant Oil stake - awaiting an IPO that never seems to happen. Mt Ida royalty if developed. I am sure that that there are assets I have probably missed, but the basic fact of life is that Red Rock are going through around £250,000 per month just to keep the lights on. The immediately saleable assets (subject to more luck that is normally associated with Red Rock/AB) might keep the lights on for 2 months but wouldn't address the underlying debt problem of the remaining £10M. What then about run rate revenue. Where could this come from? The house building project if it ever gets off the ground isn't likely to contribute anything before towards the end of 2026 if we are lucky. Burkino Faso - if we want revenue here we actually have to do something rather that pray for gold to fall from the skies. The price of gold, the price of copper, the price of silver, the price of iron are all irrelevant. Firstly they assume that Red Rock has prime assets that others are queuing up to buy. Secondly this ignores the fact that Red Rock is in a race against time. How quickly is anything saleable vs both the £250K monthly costs and the level of patience of the allegedly supportive lenders. The other factor for shareholders to consider is how much dilution will be needed and at what discount will the market demand. The only real game in town is the DRC arbitration settlement. The fact that it has been imminent for months, and now has been in the first batch to be heard for the last 2 months, doesn't inspire confidence. What else doesn't inspire confidence is the silence from Andrew Bell. No news, no broadcasts on X, nothing.

data.author: Helpful
data.content: Mr Attention-seeker, this is what the LIFE Offering document says, I know you know because you read everything. "Each Unit will consist of one common share of the Company (a “Share”) and one-half of one common share purchase warrant (each whole warrant, a “Warrant”). Each Warrant will be exercisable to acquire an additional Share (a “Warrant Share”) at an exercise price of $2.00 per Warrant Share for a period of 36 months following the Closing Date (as defined herein). The Warrants will be subject to an accelerated expiry provision such that if, for any 30 consecutive trading days (the “Premium Trading Days”) during the unexpired term of the Warrants, the closing price of the Shares exceeds $3.00, the expiry date will be accelerated to 30 calendar days (the “Acceleration Clause”). The activation of the Acceleration Clause will be announced by press release and the 30-day period will commence 7 days after the last Premium Trading Day." So for the accelerated exercise to come into play, Soma Gold share price has to close over CAD3.00 for 30 consecutive days, 7 days notice is required and then 30 days in which to exercise. Remember you said that the warrants would be worthless? So if for any 30 days period the SP closes over CAD3.00 for 29 days but one day it closes below CAD3.00 then the clock restarts. The seven days starts when the company issues the notice. So there is plenty of warning. DYOR

data.author: DAVID.M
data.content: I think some of the argument about copper is about semantics. We may have interests that are exploring for copper, but I am not aware of any JORC resource owned by those interests, nor any saleable copper that we own. My concerns with Red Rock surround whether the company has anything saleable that someone else might want to buy. Quite apart from the monthly running costs for the company, we owe POW £534,449.67 at the end of March. At present, the only two options for ready cash, if all goes well, would be the Soma warrants and the Dalaroo shares, both subject to events falling in Red Rock's favour. The current silence from the company doesn't help alleviate any of those concerns.
